fields.description:
My suggestion is to continue to include the lines which define these two variables in the eucarc returned by euca_conf --get-credentials and euca-get-credentials, as the image related commands throw an error if these variables are not defined which is hard to understand.

Also, to perhaps to have a warning issued indicating the pk and cert are no longer in the zip, but should be placed in the same location as eucarc from a previous credentials download location. This warning, and a likely more understandable error if a user attempts to use the image commands and has the env vars but is missing the files, where they’re told they’re missing the files, would I think help users figure this out quicker.
fields.summary: euca-get-credentials zip file eucarc should always define EC2_PRIVAT_KEY and EC2_CERT

comments.body: If we always put these environment variables in eucarc we risk overwriting existing environment variables (which may be set up correctly) with values that we know will not work.

Here's the problem I'm having - open to any option to address it...

I get a copy of admin.zip after a fasttart or early in a manual install. This has the pk/cert and env vars in eucarc, but the service URLs are incomplete, some not working, or using IP addresses. When I add DNS or finish system config so broken URLs are fixed, I must (or normally) re-get credentials to obtain an updated eucarc with working URLs. Before 4.1, when I did this, my eucarc would contain the env vars and the zip would contain the pk/cert these env vars pointed to, so everything still worked.

4.1.0 broke that. Now, once I finish config, or the first time I re-get credentials, actually, I'm left with a broken eucarc file, which no longer contains env vars required for the image related commands to work, despite the fact I still have valid pk/cert files from the original admin.zip expansion.

This is my suggestion, run past Vic, who suggested I create this ticket, and put in the demo scripts I'm working on, to get them working again. For me, this works, Not particularly happy or unhappy with how, but I need something other than a broken eucarc after I re-get credentials. Open to alternatives, just don't think what's there now is the right one.

This should be helpful (as cloud admin on CLC):

{code}
euca-modify-property -p authentication.access_keys_limit=10
euca-modify-property -p authentication.signing_certificates_limit=10
euca-modify-propert -p authentication.credential_download_generate_certificate=Limited
{code}

I run the above 3 commands (after source'ing my 1st eucarc) on any new install. Just helps me mitigate the problem and do custom hacks to workaround this new requirement. 

We did manage to adhere to the AWS behaviour with regards to signining certificate but we never thought of implementing a sane behaviour in our registration framework that requires multiple downloads of the creds to do simple things. As far as I know in a manual install you have to download the creds 3 times to get everything going.

Perhaps an improvement in that area is required via code and not scripts :)
echoing a warning to the user when they source the eucarc with these unset seems reasonable.

I meant to respond to Deependra's comment before, just realized I didn't.

I think the method I created for my demo install scripts is more logically correct.  There is no real logic behind creating new sets of keys and downloading them during the install process, if that can be avoided, IMHO. So, increasing the number of keys which can co-exist so the prior method remains possible seems to me more of a fix which exposed prior bad practice than a real solution.

If we're going to limit the user to only downloading credentials once - which I agree with, as the original requestor should have confidence they are the only person in possession of the private key unless they choose to share it, then I think the best solution is to figure out some way to notify them that they need to save these keys for future use which may span additional attempts to download credentials, when the purpose of such additional credentials downloads is not due to a need for new credentials (for valid reasons like a security breach or rotation), but simply the mechanics of the manual install process.

I have a new suggestion - to use a method similar to what we use now for un-configured services, where instead of the line which exports the ENV var, in the same place we have an echo statement which warns that the prior key and cert must be used. What I'd add here, is to have this warning message include the pk and cert filenames, including the unique identifier, so it's clear what files must be used.

I think this would be helpful, but I don't think this creates any additional security issues, as an additional user fetching credentials still would not have the original pk and cert files of such names.
If we weren't about to retire euca-get-credentials I would suggest adding an option that makes including the certificate optional.

I am surprised how no one is looking at the service registration process. It needs a overall change in how it is done today. I hope this is on the radar for 4.2.0 if not please make sure this gets fixed because as I see it today in front of the field audience its broken and basically a hack.

cc [~decker]
That would be EUCA-10341, [~dshekhawat].  It is currently slated for eucalyptus 4.2.0.
I think the conclusion was that we should output a warning message when sourcing eucarc if the X.509 credentials were not present.

I agree on that as far as code changes.

I think this should be accompanied by an update to the API documentation, to indicate this behavior, and to suggest that any key/cert be saved on the initial call for on-going use after additional calls.

The eucarc for the eucalyptus account now shows the following warning message if certificate credentials are not present:

{code}
# . eucarc
WARN: Certificate credentials not present.
WARN: Review authentication.credential_download_generate_certificate and
WARN: authentication.signing_certificates_limit properties for current
WARN: certificate download limits.
{code}

The eucarc for other accounts has the warning:

{code}
# . eucarc
WARN: Certificate credentials not present.
{code}

Please open issues in the Documentation (DOC) project for any desired documentation changes.

Verified.  Tested with eucalyptus and non-eucalyptus accounts.
{code}
